materials.raw_text: Cadmium (Cd): 60 g, Erbium (Er): 80 g, Nickel (Ni): 20 g, Terbium (Tb): 120 g

sourcing.instructions: Cadmium: Obtain from chemical supply companies or online suppliers specializing in metals. Erbium: Available from rare earth metal suppliers or specialty chemical vendors. Nickel: Commonly found at hardware stores or metal suppliers. Terbium: Procure from rare earth metal suppliers or chemical distributors.
steps: Cadmium: Obtain from chemical supply companies or online suppliers specializing in metals. Erbium: Available from rare earth metal suppliers or specialty chemical vendors. Nickel: Commonly found at hardware stores or metal suppliers. Terbium: Procure from rare earth metal suppliers or chemical distributors.

1. Measure out 60 g of Cadmium using a precision scale. 2. Measure 80 g of Erbium. 3. Measure 20 g of Nickel. 4. Measure 120 g of Terbium. 5. In a clean, dry mixing container, combine all measured materials thoroughly to ensure uniform distribution.
preparation.raw_text: 1. Measure out 60 g of Cadmium using a precision scale. 2. Measure 80 g of Erbium. 3. Measure 20 g of Nickel. 4. Measure 120 g of Terbium. 5. In a clean, dry mixing container, combine all measured materials thoroughly to ensure uniform distribution.

steps: 1. Transfer the mixed materials into a high-temperature furnace. 2. Heat to a temperature of 1000 °C. 3. Maintain this temperature for 2 hours to ensure complete melting and mixing of the components.
heating.raw_text: 1. Transfer the mixed materials into a high-temperature furnace. 2. Heat to a temperature of 1000 °C. 3. Maintain this temperature for 2 hours to ensure complete melting and mixing of the components.

steps: 1. After 2 hours, turn off the furnace and allow the material to cool down gradually inside the furnace to room temperature. 2. This process should take approximately 4-6 hours to avoid thermal shock.
cooling.raw_text: 1. After 2 hours, turn off the furnace and allow the material to cool down gradually inside the furnace to room temperature. 2. This process should take approximately 4-6 hours to avoid thermal shock.

steps: 1. Once cooled, remove the solidified sample from the furnace. 2. Use fine-grit sandpaper to smooth any rough edges and surfaces. 3. Optionally, apply a sealant or protective coating to preserve the integrity of the material.
post_processing.raw_text: 1. Once cooled, remove the solidified sample from the furnace. 2. Use fine-grit sandpaper to smooth any rough edges and surfaces. 3. Optionally, apply a sealant or protective coating to preserve the integrity of the material.
